awd_titl_txt: Impacts of Green Infrastructure on the Microbiome of Urban Stormwater: Reducing Threats to Public Health
awd_abstract_narration:
Green infrastructure, including bioretention cells, is increasingly used as a more sustainable alternative to traditional urban drainage. While successfully employed in many aspects of stormwater management, there is as yet no real understanding of whether or how these systems provide public health services, such as controlling the spread of human pathogens. Concentrations of fecal indicator bacteria (FIB) in stormwater routinely exceed safe levels for human contact; however, FIBs are not good indicators of actual pathogens. This highlights the need to determine the abundance and diversity of actual disease-causing pathogens and to determine how bioretention reduces their contribution to downstream water bodies. This project will address this need by analyzing the microbiome of stormwater and evaluating the effectiveness of bioretention systems in reducing a range of microbial threats in stormwater to human health and environmental quality. 

Past studies of the effectiveness of stormwater treatment technologies have been limited because conventional approaches and analytical methods only track limited bacterial species that are abundant and easy to culture, such as E. coli or coliforms. Using third generation sequencing to identify microbial species, the investigators will quantify abundance, diversity and antimicrobial resistance (AMR) genes to describe the microbiome of stormwater. The research is targeted to determine: (1) if conventional monitoring of subsets of bacteria (FIB) in stormwater is a sufficient proxy of the complete microbiome, including actual human pathogens, or if more extensive monitoring of the microbiome is warranted, and (2) if stormwater treatment technologies - in this case bioretention systems - can reduce pathogenic bacteria and AMR genes, as opposed to proxy subsets of these harmful pollutants as tracked by FIB. Through a Bioretention Design Challenge that includes field trips to the experimental watersheds, 7th and 8th grade students from Columbus City Schools will learn first-hand how to design bioretention systems and how to collect field and laboratory data to test hypotheses. Because more than 70% of Columbus City students are minorities, this will enhance the participation of underrepresented groups in STEM education. A significant societal benefit from this research will be the identification of design components that enhance stormwater pathogen reductions by green infrastructure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
1. While several studies have determined reductions in stormwater volume and improvements in water quality from one or several bioretention cells, this is one of the first studies to document stormwater reductions and improvements in water quality from a watershed scale implementation of bioretention cells. This will be helpful to urban planners, designers, engineers and architechs seeking more rationale and methods to include green infrastructure in urban settings.

2. Currently, and for many decades E. coli has been used as an indicator of pathogenic threats to public health in water. This study challenges this method by not finding a correlations between actual pathanogenic bacteria and E. coli in urban stormwater. This indicates that new techniques should be developed to determine pathanogenic threats to public health in stormwater.

3. This was the first study to examine the microbiome of urban stormwater. Main findings with implications for public health include: 1. Prevalent fecal contamination from deer populations, 2. A diverse array of antibiotic resistance genes and potentially pathanogenic bacteria, fungi, and protists identified in stormwater outflows to surface water. 3. The top 6 most abundant hosts of antibiotic resistent (AR) genes in stormwater at a phyla level were Proteobacteria, Bacteroidetes, Uroviricota, Actinobacteria, Firmicutes, and Cyanobacteria. 4. At a family level, the most abundant AR gene host family was Enterobacteriaceae. 5. One AR gene/host combination was on the CDC AR Threats List (Pseudomonas aeruginosa) and one was on the WHO Priority List of AR bacteria (Enterococcus faecium), indicating these are of great concern for public health.

We also realized important Broader Impacts by demonstrating the performance and design of green infrastructure to 7th and 8th grade students in Columbus City Schools (largest school system in Ohio). This was completed through a Bioretention Design Challenge for a 7th and 8th grade STEAM (Science, Technology,

Engineering, Arts & Math) class (35 students), and the entire 7th grade class (55

students) at Indianola Informal School. This teaching unit included the following specific activities to support two teaching goals for these middle school students: (1) learn how to design bioretention systems, and (2) how to collect and use data from the lab and field to test hypotheses while determining the effectiveness of these systems to capture and treat stormwater. Please see summary video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wfefv-d917A
